Authors:
Thomas J Near, Steven A. Nadler, James R. Garey, Michael R.
Nonnemacher
Title:
Molecular Evidence for Acanthocephala as a Subtaxon of
Rotifera.
Abstract:
Rotifers are free-living animals usually smaller than 1 mm
that possess a characteristic wheel organ. Acanthocephalans
(thorny-headed worms) are larger endoparasitic animals that use
vertebrates and arthropods to complete their life cycle. The taxa
Acantho-cephala and Rotifera are considered separate phyla, often within
the taxon Aschelminthes. We have reexamined the relationship between
Rotifera and Acanthocephala using 18S rRNA gene sequences. Our results
conclusively show that Acanthocephala is the sister group of the rotifer
class Bdelloidea. Rotifera was nonmonophy-letic in all molecular
analyses, which supports the hypothesis that the Acanthocephala
represent a taxon within the phylum Rotifera and not a separate phylum.
These results agree with a previous cladistic study of morphological
characters.
